introduction.p: Marine electric propulsion systems utilize generators to provide power for electric motors, which in turn drive the ship's propeller. The electric generators may be driven by any suitable prime mover, most commonly, diesel engines. While it may initially seem counterintuitive to interpose complex and costly equipment between the prime mover and the propeller when a simple line shaft and gearbox could transmit the power instead, there are valid justifications for the added complexity and expense.
The advantages of electric propulsion are as follows:

paragraphs.title: Layout Flexibility
paragraphs.p: One notable advantage of electric propulsion is the ability to install the prime mover in any convenient location, without being restricted to a direct line with the propeller. Power is transmitted through flexible cable runs, as opposed to rigid line shafts. Furthermore, instead of relying on a single large main engine, multiple smaller engines can be used, allowing for placement in smaller spaces and more convenient locations.

paragraphs.title: Efficient operation
paragraphs.p: Electric propulsion systems enable both the prime mover and the propeller to operate at their optimal speeds, eliminating the need for reduction gears. Typically, medium speed diesel engines are coupled with low-speed motors and propellers. The speed reduction is accomplished by selecting the appropriate number of motor poles, and the shaft speed (RPM) is established by adjusting the electrical frequency to the motor. This setup allows each component to operate within its most efficient range, maximizing overall energy efficiency and reducing fuel consumption.

paragraphs.title: Economical Part-Load Operation
paragraphs.p: By employing multiple generators operating in parallel, ships can secure one or more engines under reduced load conditions. The remaining engines can then operate at nearly full load, resulting in improved efficiency compared to having more engines operating at part-load. Load management systems continuously monitor the electrical demand and promptly initiate the startup of an additional generator when necessary.

paragraphs.title: Redundancy and Reliability
paragraphs.p: Electric propulsion systems provide inherent redundancy and enhanced reliability compared to traditional propulsion systems. With multiple smaller generator sets, the system can continue to function even if one or more generators or motors fail or require maintenance. This redundancy reduces the risk of complete propulsion failure and ensures that the propulsion system remains operational.

subsection.title: Principle of operation
subsection.p: An electrical generator converts mechanical energy into electrical energy by utilizing the principle of electromagnetic induction. Electromagnetic induction was first discovered in the early 19th century by English scientist Michael Faraday (1791 1867) . According to Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction, a changing magnetic field induces an electric voltage in a nearby conductor. If the conductor forms a closed loop, an electric current will flow through it.

A generator consists of two main components: a rotating part called the rotor and a stationary part called the stator. In a typical AC synchronous generator, the rotor carries the field windings which produce the magnetic field, and the stator carries the armature windings, where the voltage is induced.

A direct current (DC) is passed through the rotor's field windings to create the magnetic field. The process of supplying electrical current to the field winding is known as excitation. Alternately, some generators use permanent magnets to supply the magnetic field, but this has the disadvantage that the field is not adjustable. The rotor is connected to a prime mover, such as a steam turbine or a diesel engine, and as it spins it produces a rotating magnetic field.

The stator consists of multiple windings arranged in a specific configuration. The rotating magnetic field interacts with the stator windings, inducing a voltage across them. If the stator winding are connected to a closed circuit containing a load like a motor or resistor, the induced voltage drives current through the circuit and transmits power to load.

The induced voltage is proportional to the speed of rotation and also the strength of the magnetic field, therefore the output voltage can be adjusted by controlling the excitation current. The frequency in Hz (cycles/sec) depends on the speed of rotation and the number of magnetic poles. f = \frac{P \;n }{120} where
f = frequency
n= speed
P = number of north/south pole pairs
The induced voltage is typically generated at a fixed frequency, such as 60 Hz in the United States.

To generate three-phase power, the stator is fitted with three windings arranged symmetrically, 120 degrees apart from each other. As the rotor rotates, the rotating magnetic field induces voltages into each stator winding in turn, generating three sine waves of voltage, equally spaced, shown in .

subsection.title: Excitation
subsection.p: The pilot generator is used to supply current to the exciter field, making the main generator separately excited, as opposed to self excited, where the output of the main generator itself is used to supply power to the the exciter generator. The AC output voltage of the pilot generator varies with the rotor speed, however its output current is automatically adjusted by an Automatic Voltage Regulator (AVR) to maintain its rated output (terminal) voltage, regardless of the load changes.

The pilot generator consists of stator and rotor part as shown in and . The rotor part carries sixteen permanent magnets bolted on the shaft with alternating polarities making this a Permanent Magnet Generator (PMG). The stator part is bolted on the bearing housing of non drive-end side of the generator and carries 3-phase wye-connected armature windings. The rotating magnets induce an AC voltage into the armature windings and three-phase rectifier attached to the stator converts the AC voltage to a DC voltage.
The resulting DC voltage is used to create a stationary magnetic field in the exciter. In other words, the pilot generator excites the exciter, which in turn excites the main generator.
